i_am_kimpossible: @evyan.whitney thank you for sharing ! My bf and I recently moved in together and we have separate rooms, which some think is weird (whatever that means 🤷🏻‍♀️). beeee_youtifullll: i love this so much. all of this.
eevolves: My partner and I decided to do the same thing last year when I moved back to my hometown after being together for 6 years and living together for 4 of them. It’s been THE BEST thing that we’ve ever done for our relationship. Congratulations!!!
lydiabeingalive: Ahhh I'm so happy for you both, that you've found a new way to be together, while honouring your other individual needs/ desires. So much love coming your way 💜
kikicarlstrom: Just finished the podcast! Firstly, I love hearing your soothing and sweet voice 😌 it’s been a while. And second, it really sparked such an important conversation for my partner and I around ultimate freedom and how much do we allow to just die within ourselves because fighting for it was harder than just giving up on the need for whatever the freedom was. I think of my mother who has sacrificed the last 26 years living in the suburbs when she deeply wants to move to NW Portland, but she allows that dream to simply die within her because advocating for herself feels too hard. Easier to allow her husband to have what he wants; a suburban life. Anyways, your pod applies to so many different aspects of life and I’m also jazzed to learn a new term (LAT)!
tefylh: thank you for this 💕 sharing your experiences makes for incredible source of knowledge and inspiration
chichi_bombbomb: Thank you for sharing your story. I’m so happy for you that you’ve chosen to prioritize your self! It takes so much courage to take that leap. I’m excited for your journeys together - apart.
chereeselavonne: i haven’t even listened to your podcast yet, but have in recent times been trying to negotiate my own desire to be in intentional relationship, but also considering that living with my partner may take away from the individuality we celebrate. just seeing that there is consideration elsewhere in the world along these lines give me some release to continue to follow my intuition on this. thank you for sharing and for showing up in the world in the way you do.
spitblue: thank you for sharing this, i’m grateful to encounter pages like your whet you can find very relatable experiences or just an insight to life which can help others guide through theirs. i appreciate you ❤️
lillierinyoga: Loved loved loved reading your transcript. Felt like I was reading a heartfelt letter from an old friend. Thank you so much for providing a transcript too - this is rare, much to the frustration of deaf folks. Thank you again for sharing your story - it’s soul fillin’ stuff ❤️

lesliefender: My husband and I started “living apart together” last year and I’d say this unconventional transition supported more than threatened our 24-year marriage. His lease was up at the end of March and we’re back under the same roof combining our resources during the uncertainty of this pandemic disaster. There are definite benefits and challenges to this new-yet-old arrangement right now, but we both agree we’ll return to separate households whenever/if things return to “normal.” Honestly, neither situation is for the faint of heart. Long term relationships are a beautiful thing, and not without their battles. Thanks so much for sharing. I look forward to listening to your podcast.
tealeigh: Thank you for sharing that. This is a very relatable and I think important thing to share so I appreciate the openness. I would really love to try this with my partner and I one day. You’re an incredible human being, one that I’m lucky to have met 🖤
rebeccaweger: I love hearing stories about how folks buck expectations and find living arrangements that work for them.
